p: Other than effective prophylaxis or therapeutic cures, few things are more important in a pandemic than knowing who is infected (and infectious). In a matter of months after SARS-CoV-2 infections spread worldwide, most governments struggled with trying to quickly determine the most fundamental aspect of the pandemic â€” the distribution and magnitude of infected populations. This problem was greatly exacerbated by the fact that facile transmission of the virus could be accomplished via the air and that a major vector of transmission was always concealed as an unknown portion of the asymptomatic general population. This greatly increased the difficulty in efficiently directing the public health resources essential for the containment, control, or mitigation of transmission. Moreover, possibly the most successful approach is total suppression ( Casella, 2020), which requires an especially early warning.
